steps: Weigh raw materials according to the stoichiometric ratio and ball-mill with zirconia balls in nylon jars for 12 hours.
Add 2 wt% of PbO to compensate for volatilization during sintering.
Dry the mixture at 120°C.
Calcine the dried powders at 900°C for 4 hours.
Re-mill the calcined powders for 6 hours.
Mix the powders with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder and sieve through a screen mesh.
Press the powders into pellets with a diameter of 12 mm and thickness around 1.2 mm under uniaxial pressure of 15 MPa.
Fire the green pellets at 500°C for 2 hours for binder burn-out.
Sinter all specimens at 1190–1250°C for 1 hour.
Control cooling at 3°C/min down to 600°C to prevent cracking, then naturally cool below 600°C.
Determine optimal sintering temperature (1230°C) via bulk density analysis.
For annealing, heat polarized samples from room temperature to different annealing temperatures at 3°C/min, hold for 0.5 hours, then cool naturally.
Heat untreated samples to 350°C at 3°C/min, hold for 2 hours, then cool before annealing.
Polarize samples in silicon oil at 150°C with a DC electric field up to 4 kV/mm for 30 minutes.
Measure d33 using a quasi-static d33 tester at room temperature.

steps: Weigh raw chemicals according to the stoichiometric ratio.
Ball-mill the mixture in ethanol for 12 hours.
Dry the mixture.
Calcine at 1250°C for 2 hours with a heating rate of 5°C/min.
Ball-mill the calcined powder again in ethanol for 12 hours.
Dry the powder at 90°C for 3 hours.
Press the mixture into pellets with 8 mm diameter using 5 wt% PVA as binder.

steps: Dry all raw materials at approximately 120°C for 5 hours.
Weigh raw materials according to the desired composition.
Mix raw materials by ball milling for 12 hours with ethanol as a medium.
Calcine the dried raw materials at 850°C for 2 hours to obtain the ceramic composition.
Second ball milling of calcined powder for 12 hours to reduce particle size.
Dry the calcined powder and granulate through an 80 mesh sieve.
Add polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) aqueous solution (5 wt.%) as a binder, approximately 10 wt.% of powder mass.
Press the powder into green bodies and heat to 800°C for 2 hours to remove binder.
Sinter the green bodies at 1140°C-1180°C for 2 hours.
Heat the sintered ceramics to 1100°C for 1 hour.
Rapidly cool the ceramics in air from 1100°C.
Polish the ceramic disks and anneal at 500°C prior to characterization.

steps: Weigh raw materials according to the stoichiometric ratio of the general formula.
Mix raw materials by ball-milling with ZrO2 balls in ethanol for 12 hours.
Dry the mixture.
Calcine the dried mixture at 850°C for 2 hours.
Ball-mill the calcined powder for an additional 24 hours.
Ground and granulate the powders with PVA binder.
Press into discs of 12 mm diameter and 1 mm thickness under 150 MPa pressure.
Remove PVA binder by heating at 650°C.
Sinter the green samples in a muffle furnace at 1150°C for 3 hours for CaBi2Nb2O9, or at 1100–1140°C for 3 hours for thulium-substituted ceramics.

Prepare textured ceramics using a two-step spark plasma sintering (SPS) process: place powders into a graphite die (inner diameter 10 mm), heat to 990°C for 3 min under 60 MPa, deform in another graphite die (inner diameter 20 mm) at 1130°C for 5 min under 40 MPa, then anneal at 1000°C for 4 hours in air.

synthesis_data.method: Methods: Screen printing, firing, sputtering, diffusion bonding, thermal cycling, repoling
steps: Sourcing PZT ceramic discs of grade SP-6
Measuring and selecting discs based on back wall echo amplitude
Coating both sides of PZT discs with silver using screen printing with proprietary silver paste
Firing PZT discs at approximately 800°C in air to form silver electrodes
Assessing bond quality via ultrasonic C-scan imaging
Preparing nickel wear plates from Ni-200 rods, grinding to achieve planarity and roughness
Coating nickel wear plates with silver via DC sputtering to about 6 μm thickness
Heating coated nickel plates in flowing hydrogen at 700°C for 2 hours to diffuse silver into nickel and form a metallurgical bond
Applying an additional silver coating (~3 μm) to reach a total of approximately 9 μm thickness
Assembling PZT discs and nickel plates in a vessel with a sample holder, evacuating to high vacuum (< -E^{10}E^{2} Pa)
Heating the assembly in a split furnace up to 275°C or 400°C, applying 20 MPa pressure for 1 hour for diffusion bonding
Cooling the assembly to room temperature after bonding
Performing thermal cycling between 250°C and room temperature with heating rate of 3°C/hour, holding at 250°C for 2 hours, then cooling
Measuring d33 piezoelectric coefficient before and after bonding and thermal cycles
Repoling PZT discs at 150°C in dry silicone oil with 15 kV DC potential for 15 minutes
Evaluating bond quality and piezoelectric properties post-repoling

steps: Combine high-purity Eu2O3, GeO2, Dy2O3, La2O3, and Ho2O3 in stoichiometric ratios.
Dopant 5 mol% of Dy2O3, La2O3, and Ho2O3 into the respective compositions Eu1.90Dy0.10Ge2O7, Eu1.90La0.10Ge2O7, Eu1.90Ho0.10Ge2O7.
Conduct thermal analysis using DTA/TG up to 1300°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min to study decomposition and oxidation.
Pre-sinter the powder mixtures at 800°C for 2 hours.
Milling of the powder mixtures followed by sintering at 1150°C for 10 hours in alumina crucibles under open atmosphere.
Cool the samples slowly after sintering.
Perform XRD analysis after sintering at 1150°C.
Form ceramic discs (1 mm thickness, 10 mm diameter) by uniaxial pressing at 250 MPa with 2 wt% PVA binder.
Heat the pressed discs at 600°C for 30 min to remove organic additives.
Sinter the discs at 1400°C for 4 hours.
Apply silver paste to the surfaces, then fire at 650°C for 1 hour to form electrodes.
Polish the discs with emery paper (1200 grit).
Fire the discs again at 650°C for 1 hour to finalize surface electrodes.
Measure dielectric and piezoelectric properties, including loss tangent and d33, after applying electric field in silicon oil bath at 120°C for 30 min and aging for 24 hours.

Sinter the debound samples at 1350°C for 2 hours.

steps: Weigh raw powders of (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3, BaCO3, TiO2, and MnO2 according to the chemical formula.
Ball-mill the powders with zirconia balls (1 mm diameter) and ethanol at 250 rpm for 16 hours.
Dry the mixture at 80°C.

Pass the mixture through a 250 μm mesh.
Mix about 0.5 g of the powder with a SrTiO3 seed crystal.
Press the mixture into a disc compact (10 mm diameter) at 200 MPa with the seed crystal at the center.
Heat the compacts at 700°C for 2 hours in air to remove binder.
Sinter the compacts at 1200°C for 24 hours in air in a box-type electric furnace with heating and cooling rates of 150°C/h.

steps: Dissolve Ta2O5, CH3COOLi2H2O, and C4H6O6 separately in ethanol.
Mix the solutions with commercial LCO powders and vigorously stir.
Evaporate the mixed solution and stir at 80°C until a sol forms.
Age the sol at 120°C for 10 hours to obtain a gel.
Anneal the gel at 500°C for 12 hours and then cool to room temperature.
Prepare pure LTO by similar process without adding LCO, then compact into disks using uniaxial pressing with polyvinyl butyral binder.
Sinter the LTO disks in air at 500°C for 3 hours.

steps: Synthesize MgNb2O6 at 1000°C and ScNbO4 at 1150°C from MgO, Sc2O3, and Nb2O5.
Select and weigh MgNb2O6, ScNbO4, TiO2, and PbO powders according to stoichiometric proportions, adding 2 mol% extra PbO to compensate for vaporization.
Mix powders with alcohol in a 1:1 ratio via wet-milling for 24 hours.
Calcine the mixture at 800–850°C for 2 hours.
Mix the calcined powder again for 12 hours.
Conglutinate the powder with PVA solution and press into tablets under 8 MPa.
Burn off PVA at 550°C for 2 hours.
Cover tablets with powders of the same composition to maintain Pb-rich atmosphere and sinter at 1200–1280°C for 4 hours.
Polish the sintered samples into cylindrical disks, coat with silver electrodes, and perform electrical poling at 130°C for 15 minutes under 30 kV/cm electric field.

steps: Dissolve 0.011 mol Bi(NO3)3 and 0.01 mol Fe(NO3)3·H2O into 100 mL deionized water to prepare aqueous solutions of 0.11 M and 0.1 M respectively, adding 3 mL nitric acid to Bi(NO3)3 solution until fully dissolved.
Mix the two solutions and add 0.02 mol triammonium citrate as a complexing agent, then stir for 30 min.
Continuously stir the mixture at 90°C until water evaporates, forming a gel.
Calcine the gel at 550°C for 2 hours to obtain pure phase BiFeO3 powder.
Prepare CdS nanosheets by adding 10 mL of 0.3 M cadmium chloride solution to 50 mL of 0.1 M sodium citrate solution, stirring at room temperature for 20 min.
Add 3 mL concentrated ammonia and 10 mL of 0.6 M thiourea sequentially, then react in a water bath at 60°C for 2.5 hours.
Cool naturally, centrifuge to collect precipitate, rinse with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, then dry at 60°C to obtain CdS nanosheets.
Prepare BFO/CdS composites by dispersing 0.6 g of BFO into 60 mL of 0.1 M sodium citrate solution, adding 1.38 mL of 0.3 M cadmium chloride (for 10 wt%) and stirring for 3 hours.
Add 3.6 mL concentrated ammonia and 1.38 mL of 0.9 M thiourea slowly, then react at 60°C in a water bath for 2.5 hours.
Collect, rinse with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, and dry at 60°C to obtain the composite samples BC10, BC20, BC30 with varying CdS content.

Characterize phase structure using XRD.
Analyze surface morphology with SEM.

steps: Weigh high purity chemical powders stoichiometrically.
Ball mill powders for 24 hours at 300 rpm with alumina balls using acetone as mixing media.
Dry the mixed powders in an oven.
Calcine the dried powders at 900°C for 3 hours.
Press the calcined powders into disc-shaped pellets (~13 mm diameter) under uniaxial pressure of 200 MPa.
Sinter the pellets at 1150–1200°C for 2–4 hours.
Measure the density of sintered pellets using Archimedes principle.
Ground and anneal the pellets at 500°C for 1 hour for XRD measurements.
Electroded the samples on both sides with silver paste and annealed at 500°C for 1 hour for electrical measurements.
Thinned samples to ~1 mm thickness for dielectric measurements.
Poling performed by applying 4–5 kV/mm DC field for 15–30 minutes in silicone oil bath.
Perform dielectric measurements using LCR meter over temperature range 25°C–600°C at various frequencies.
Measure piezoelectric coefficient (d33) with d33 meter.
Perform ferroelectric and strain measurements using loop tracer and strain setup at 1 Hz.
Conduct XRD measurements on Empyrean, Malvern Panalytical with Cu Kα radiation.

Ball mill the mixture to ensure homogeneity.
Calcine the mixture at an appropriate temperature to promote solid-state diffusion and reaction.
Press the calcined powder into pellets.
Sinter the pellets at high temperature to achieve densification and ceramic formation.

steps: Prepare 0.1 M solution by dissolving equimolar quantities of Lanthanum (III) nitrate and Nickel (II) nitrate in glacial acetic acid, add 0.01 M ethylene glycol, and stir for 1 hour.
Prepare 0.3 M solution by dissolving Ti-n butoxide in glacial acetic acid, add 0.01 M ethylene glycol, and stir for 1 hour.
Prepare 0.1 M solution by dissolving Lead (II) acetate in glacial acetic acid, then separately add stoichiometric amounts of Zirconium (IV) n-butoxide and Titanium (IV) n-butoxide, and stir.
Add appropriate amount of distilled water and ethylene glycol, stir for 30 minutes.
Add 10 wt% polyvinyl pyrrolidone, stir for 1 hour, then filter using Whatman filter paper.
Deposit buffer layers (TiO, LNO, LNO/TiO) on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrates by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 seconds, then anneal at 650°C for 30 minutes.
Deposit PZT films by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 seconds, followed by two-step annealing at 400°C for 2 minutes and 650°C for 2 minutes.
Repeat the coating and annealing cycle 12 times to achieve ~1000 nm thickness, then anneal at 650°C for 30 minutes.

Characterize the crystallinity and phase via XRD, microstructure via FESEM, buffer layer thickness via FIB, grain size via image analysis, ferroelectric properties via Sawyer-Tower circuit, dielectric properties via impedance analyzer, leakage current via two-probe station, and temperature-dependent properties via hot-chuck.

steps: Grow single crystal along [001] using the modified Bridgman method.
Cut the crystal into unit sheets of 6 x 6 x 0.38 mm.
Anneal the unit sheets at 600°C for 4 hours and clean.
Deposit 100 nm thick gold layers on the surface of unit sheets via sputtering.
Leave 0.5 mm wide insulating margins on alternating upper and lower surfaces during electrode plating.
Perform direct current polarization (DCP) along [001] at 135°C, 1 kV/mm for 10 minutes in a thermostatic oil bath.
Subject polarized sheets to electrical testing for property analysis.
Bond 15 layers of unit sheets with epoxy in electrical parallel and mechanical series configuration.
Attach zirconia ceramic sheets (0.5 mm thick) to top and bottom for rigidity.
Apply 5 MPa pressure using an isostatic press and cure for 48 hours.
Finish the assembled PSAs with dimensions 6 x 6 x 6.7 mm.
Examine internal structure with polarized light microscopy.
Record strain-electric field (S-E) characteristics under varying electric field frequency and amplitude.
Adjust temperature from 25°C to 115°C, maintaining each temperature for 1 hour before measurement.

steps: Weigh raw materials according to stoichiometry.
Ball-mill raw materials in alcohol for 24 hours to reduce particle size.

Sieve the dried powder for uniform particle size.
Calcine the powder at 900°C for 6 hours.
Press the calcined powder into pellets using uniaxial pressing at 100–200 MPa.
Sinter the pellets at 1120–1140°C for 3 hours.
Disperse ceramic powder in ethyl alcohol using sonication for 3 hours.
Mix dispersed powder with PDMS in various proportions (0–30 wt%) and add curing agent (ratio 10:1).
Load mixture into a syringe, pour into mold, and cure at room temperature for 48 hours.
Cut dried composite films into sheets of 3×3 cm with 3 mm thickness.
Polish samples, coat with silver paste, and fire at 600°C for 30 minutes for dielectric, piezoelectric, and ferroelectric characterization.

synthesis_data.method: molten salt method, solid-state reaction, ball milling, tape casting, sintering
steps: Synthesize [001]-oriented BTO template powders from Bi2O3 and TiO2 using molten salt method with NaCl and KCl in 1:1 wt ratio.
Sinter the template powder at 1100°C for 1 hour.
Prepare BTO matrix powders via solid-state reaction by weighing Bi2O3 and TiO2 according to stoichiometric ratio.
Calcine raw materials at 700°C for 2 hours.
Ball mill calcined powder for 48-72 hours to achieve small particle size.
Mix template and matrix powders by ball milling at ~60 rpm using xylene and ethanol as solvents.
Add 5 vol% of BTO template to the solution and stir for 1 hour for homogenization.
Perform tape casting with a blade gap of 210 μm.
Dry tapes at room temperature for 8-10 hours.
Cut dried tapes into 10×10 mm squares and laminate under 75 MPa pressure for 1-3 hours.
Burn off organics at 600°C for 3 hours.
Heat green bodies in a tube furnace from 650°C to 1000°C at 10°C/min to assess texture evolution.
Sinter green bodies in oxygen atmosphere at 950°C for 0-6 hours to measure electrical properties.

article_metadata.title: Enhanced electrical properties in textured Bi4Ti3O12 ceramics with negative strain

steps: Powders of CaCO3, Na2CO3, Pr6O11, CeO2, Bi2O3, and TiO2 were ground using a planetary ball mill for 12 hours with anhydrous ethanol as solvent.
The mixture was dried at 70°C for 6 hours.
Dried powders were calcined for 4 hours at 850°C.
0.2 wt% MnO2 was added to the calcined powders.
The calcined powders were ground again using planetary ball mill for 12 hours and dried.
A 6 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder was added to the powders.
The powders were pressed into discs under a pressure of 6–8 MPa.
Discs were heated at 600°C for 2 hours to remove PVA.
Pellets were sintered in air at 950°C–1050°C for 2.5 hours.
characterization_techniques: P–E and I–E hysteresis loop measurement

steps: Mix precursors in their respective stoichiometric ratios.
Add propan-2-ol and acetic acid as solvents, and pentane-2,4-dione as polymerizing agent.
Stir the mixture at room temperature at 700 rpm for seven days to allow polymerization.
Deposit six layers of BNKT-20-3M on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate via spin-coating at 500 rpm for 10 s and then at 4000 rpm for 30 s per layer.
Perform heat treatments including evaporation at 200°C, pyrolysis at 500°C, and annealing at 750°C, each for 5 min, repeating the sequence six times to achieve approximately 220 nm thickness.
Optionally, further heat-treat some samples in nitrogen atmosphere at 750°C for 30 min for defect passivation.

steps: Synthesis of matrix powder using solid state reaction: mixing raw materials and sintering at 750°C for 2 hours.
Preparation of BaTiO3 templates via topochemical transformation: slicing embryo strips, stacking, compressing at 70°C with 10 MPa for 30 minutes, sintering at 550°C for 2 hours to discharge organics.
Sample shaping: isostatic pressing at 200 MPa for 1 minute.
Final sintering in air atmosphere at 1200–1270°C for 0–11 hours to achieve textured ceramics.

steps: Mix raw materials PbO, NiO, Nb2O5, ZrO2, and TiO2 in appropriate ratios.
Ball-mill the mixture using zirconia balls for 24 hours.
Dry the mixture at 90°C.
Calcine the dried powders at 850°C for 4 hours with a heating rate of 5°C/min.
Add 0.2 wt% Li2CO3 as a sintering aid to the calcined powders.
Ball-mill the calcined powders with zirconia balls for 48 hours.
Dry the mixture at 90°C.
Prepare slurry by mixing PNNZT powders with ethyl alcohol, toluene, dibutyl phthalate, polyvinyl butyral, and dispersant, followed by 24 hours ball-milling.
Separate the slurry from zirconia balls and remove air bubbles using a vacuum chamber for 15 minutes.
Age the slurry for 2 hours at 15 rpm.
Cast BT-template-free thick sheets via tape casting at a speed of 1 m/min with a blade gap of 85 μm, resulting in 17 μm thick sheets.
Disperse BT templates in ethanol using sonication for 5 minutes, then add to the slurry.
Remove remaining air bubbles and age the slurry for 2 hours at 15 rpm.
Cast BT-included thin sheets via tape casting at a speed of 1 m/min with a blade gap of 8 μm, resulting in 5 μm thick sheets.
Alternately laminate PNNZT and PNNZT-BT sheets under 10 MPa pressure at 60°C.
Apply warm isostatic pressing at 25 MPa and 65°C for 20 minutes to densify laminates.
Cut laminates into 10 mm x 10 mm pieces.
Burn out organic components by firing at 300°C and 600°C for 5 hours each with a heating rate of 1°C/min.
Press the fired laminates using cold isostatic pressing at 200 MPa for 1 minute.
Sinter the pressed specimens at temperatures from 900°C to 1025°C for 15 hours under O2 atmosphere with flow rate 1 L/min and heating rate 1°C/min.
Apply Ag paste on both sides and fire at 700°C for 10 minutes.
Poling at 3.5 kV/mm for 20 minutes in silicone oil.

steps: Mix precursors homogenously for 12 hours using planetary ball mill with zirconia jar and zirconia balls in presence of acetone.
Calcine the mixed powder at approximately 900°C for 5 hours to obtain pure phase powder.
Mix calcined powder with 3 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) solution in deionized water as organic binder.
Press the mixture into pellets of 12 mm and 14 mm diameter using uniaxial pressure die at 100 MPa.
Sinter the green pellets at 1190°C for 2 hours inside a muffle furnace, sealing inside alumina crucible with MgO spacer powder.
Crush the sintered pellet and anneal at 600°C for 4 hours to remove mechanical strains.
Analyze the annealed pellet using X-ray diffraction.
Cover dense pellets with silver paste and bake at 250°C for 45 minutes for poling.
Polish and pole the ceramic pellets in silicone oil bath at room temperature for 1 hour with a DC electric field of 40 kV/cm.
Ground poled pellets into fine powder and perform XRD to examine phase transformation.
Measure piezoelectric coefficient (d33) after poling at room temperature for 1 hour at 40 kV/cm.
Perform dielectric dispersion and permittivity measurements using impedance analyzer.
Record Raman spectra using a 532 nm laser line on a LabRam HR spectrometer with a microscope.
Derive pair distribution function using PDFgetX3 software from total X-ray scattering data acquired at DESY's PETRA III beam line.

steps: Weigh raw materials according to the desired composition.
Pour raw materials and ethanol into a jar and ball mill for 24 hours with ZrO2 balls.
Dry the milled powders.
Calcine the dried powders at 850°C for 6 hours.
Mix the calcined powders with the corresponding proportions of raw materials, add ethanol, and ball mill again for 24 hours.
Dry the mixed powders.
Granulate the dried powders into a floc with 8 wt% PVA as binder.
Press the granulated powders into disks (1 mm thick, 10 mm diameter) under 10 MPa pressure.
Remove PVA binder.
Buried disks in calcined powders and sinter at 1150°C for 3 hours in air.
Heat from room temperature to 1000°C at 5°C/min, then beyond 1000°C at 3°C/min.
Process samples with silver electrodes at 600°C for 10 minutes.

steps: Weigh high-purity oxides according to the stoichiometric ratio.

Dry the mixture in an oven.
Calcine the dried mixture at 850°C for 3 hours.
Ball-mill the calcined powder in ethanol for 12 hours.
Dry and granulate the powder with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol.
Sieve the granulated powder through an 80-mesh screen to obtain uniform particles.
Uniaxially dry press the powder into pellets with 10 mm diameter and 1.5 mm thickness.
Sinter the pressed samples in ambient air at a rate of 3°C/min, reaching 1120–1200°C for 2 hours after binder removal at 550°C.

Microstructure investigation using SEM with back-scattered electron detection.
Electrical characterization including hysteresis, leakage current, and piezoelectric coefficient measurements performed on sliced samples.

steps: Weigh high purity K2CO3, Na2CO3, Nb2O5, Sb2O3, CaCO3, ZrO2, Ag2O, and Bi2O3 powders according to stoichiometry.
Mix powders by ball-milling in anhydrous ethanol for 24 hours.
Calcine the mixture at 850°C for 5 hours to form the main perovskite phase.
Prepare slurry by mixing the calcined powders with NaNbO3 templates in ethanol/toluene with PVB binder and MnO2 sintering aid.
Tape cast the slurry into green tapes using a doctor blade with 30–50 μm thickness.
Dry the green tapes, cut, stack, and uniaxially press at 15 MPa at 70°C for 20 minutes.
Remove organic binder by heating to 600°C.
Sinter the pressed samples by heating to 1190°C, then rapidly cool to 1090°C and dwell for 10 hours.

steps: Weigh high-purity raw materials according to the stoichiometry ratio.
Ball mill the raw materials with ethyl alcohol for 12 hours at 300 rpm.
Dry the powders after milling.
Divide powders into four batches and calcine at 800°C, 850°C, 900°C, and 950°C respectively.
Press part of the calcined powders into 10 mm diameter compacts at 200 MPa using cold isostatic pressing (group A).
Ball mill the residual powders for 24 hours, then press into pellets under the same conditions (group B).
Sinter all pellets using a two-step sintering process: heat rapidly to 1190°C at 10°C/min, then cool rapidly to 1090°C and hold for 5 hours, followed by natural cooling.

steps: Accurately weigh raw materials according to the specified composition.
Mill the raw materials with ethanol for 16 hours.
Dry the powders at 100°C.
Calcine the powders at 1150°C for 3 hours.
Re-mill the calcined powders with ethanol for 16 hours.
Press the powders into 9 mm diameter disks using 3% PVA solution as binder.
Fire the pressed disks at 600°C for 2 hours.
Sinter the disks at 1400°C for 3 hours.
Polish the sintered ceramics and coat with silver paste on top and bottom surfaces.
Fire the coated ceramics at 800°C for 30 minutes to form electrodes.
Pole the ceramics at 50 kV/cm DC field for 30 minutes in silicone oil bath.

article_metadata.title: Study on curie temperature mechanism and electrical properties of BiFeO3-doped (Ba,Ca) (Ti,Sn)O3 ceramics

steps: Synthesize Li-doped BaTiO3 ceramics with varying Li content (0 wt%, 2 wt%, 4 wt%) using solvothermal approach.
Press the powders into pellets.
Sinter the pellets in a closed environment at 1100°C for 2 hours.
Perform Rietveld refinement to confirm single-phase tetragonal structure.
Conduct elemental analysis to confirm the presence of barium and titanium.
Use Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) to observe nanoparticle formation and measure particle size.
Analyze SAED patterns with CrysTBox software to confirm polycrystalline nature.

article_metadata.title: Machine learning assisted innovative strategy for experimental validation of functional properties of lead-free ceramics

steps: Mix high-purity precursors in stoichiometric ratios.
Grind the mixture in a mortar and pestle for 2 hours.
Mill the mixture for 4 hours in ethanol with zirconia balls using a low-energy ball mill.
Dry the milled solution and pulverize lumps.
Calcine the pulverized powders at 1200°C for 4 hours in air.
Regrind the calcined powders and mold into disk-shaped pellets (1 mm thick, 10 mm diameter) with 1 wt% PVA binder.
Heat the pellets at 650°C for 1 hour at 1°C/min to burn off PVA binder.
Sinter the binder-free pellets simultaneously at 1400°C for 4 hours in air.

steps: Mix 1 g colemanite, 80 mg Fe2O3, 500 mg BaCO3, and 500 mg TiO2.
Ball mill the mixture for 15 hours at 300 rpm.
Add 2 mL of 13.8 M ammonia solution to the milled mixture.
Ball mill for an additional 3 minutes at the same rotational speed.
Transfer the mixture onto a silicon carbide plate (3 cm x 2 cm).
Evaporate ammonia by heating the plate on a hot plate at 150°C.
Place the residual mixture with the SiC plate into a tubular furnace.
Heat the furnace gradually to 1300°C and maintain for 3 hours under NH3 flow.
Stop NH3 flow at 975°C and allow the furnace to cool to room temperature.
Collect the composite from the SiC plate.

steps: Weigh raw materials according to the nominal composition of Bi3-xCexTiNbO9.
Ball mix the raw materials with anhydrous ethanol and zirconia balls medium for 24 hours.
Separate the balls, dry the mixed slurry.
Calcine the dried powders at 800°C for 3 hours.
Ball mill the calcined powders again for 24 hours.
Granulate the dried powders using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA, 5 wt%) as adhesive.
Press the granulated powders into green pellets of 13 mm diameter and about 1.0 mm thickness under a pressure of 120 ± 10 MPa.
Fire the green pellets at 650°C for 3 hours to burn off PVA.
Sinter the fired pellets at 1065°C–1105°C for 3 hours in air with a heating rate of 5°C/min, followed by furnace cooling to ambient temperature.
